B-trees, Shadowin
Clones
Ohad Rodeh

Talk outline
PrefaceBasics of getting b-trees to work with shPerformance resultsAlgorithms for cloning (writable-snapsh

Introduction
The talk is about a free technique usefu
file-systems like ZFS and WAFL
It is appropriate for this forum due to th
port of ZFS to Linux
The ideas described here were used in prototype of an object-disk.A b-tree was used for the OSD catalog 
extent-tree was used for objects (files).

Shadowing
Some file-systems use shadowing: WABasic idea:
1. File-system is a tree of fixed-sized p
2. Never overwrite a page
For every command:
1. Write a short logical log entry
2. Perform the operation on pages writ
side
3. Perform a checkpoint once in a while

Shadowing II
In case of crash: revert to previous stab
and replay the log
Shadowing is used for: Snapshots, cras
write-batching, RAID

Shadowing III
Important optimizations
1. Once a page is shadowed, it does n
shadowed again until the next check
2. Batch dirty-pages and write them se
disk

Snapshots
Taking snapshots is easy with shadowinIn order to create
a snapshot:
1. The file-system allows more than
a s
2.
A checkpoint is taken
but not erased

B-trees
B-trees are used by many file-systems 
files and directories: XFS, JFS, ReiserF
They guarantee logarithmic-time key-se
remove
The main questions:
1. Can we use B-trees to represent files and d
conjunction with shadowing?
2. Can we get good concurrency?3. Can we supports lots of clones efficiently?

Challenges
Challenge to multi-threading: changes 
the root. The root is a contention point.
In a regular b-tree the leaves can be linneighbors.
Not possible in conjunction with sha
Throws out a lot of the existing b-tree lit

The solution:
insert-key
Top-downLock-coupling for concurrencyProactive splitShadowing on the way downInsert element 8

2. Inserts into [6,7]

Analysis for
Insert/Remove-k
Always hold two/three locksAt most three pages held at any timeModify a single path in the tree

Pros/Cons
Cons:
Effectively lose two keys per node d
split/merge policy
Need loose bounds on number of en
(b . . . 3b)
Pros:
No deadlocks, no need for deadlock
detection/avoidance
Relatively simple algorithms, adapta
controllers

Cloning
To clone a b-tree means to create a wri
that allows all operations: lookup, inser
delete.
A cloning algorithm has several desirab

Cloning properti
Assume p is a b-tree and q is a clone of 
1. Space efficiency: p and q should, as 
possible, share common pages
2. Speed: creating q from p should take 
overhead
3. Number of clones: it should be poss
many times
4. Clones as first class citizens: it shou
to clone q

Cloning, a naive
solution
A trivial algorithm for cloning a tree is c
wholesale.
This does not have the above four prop

WAFL free-space
There are deficiencies in the classic WAA bit is used to represent each cloneWith a map of 32-bits per data block we To support 256 clones, 32 bytes are ne
data-block.
In order to clone a volume or delete a c
make a pass on the entire free-space

Challenges
How do we support a million clones without a hu
map?
How do we avoid making a pass on the entire fr

Main idea
Modify the free space so it will keep a r(ref-count) per blockRef-count records how many times a paA zero ref-count means that a block is fEssentially, instead of copying a tree, th
all its nodes are incremented by one
This means that all nodes belong to two 
of one; they are all shared
Instead of making a pass on the entire 
incrementing the counters during the cl
this is done in a lazy fashion.

Cloning a tree
1. Copy the root-node of p into a new root
2. Increment the free-space counters for e
children of the root by one

The addition of ref-counts does not add

quickly broken and each clone gets its o

FS counters
The number of free-space accesses inc
Potential of significantly impacting perfo
Several observations make this unlikely
1. Once sharing is broken for a page a
single tree, there are no additional re
associated with it.
2. The vast majority of b-tree pages ar
Leaves have no children and therefo
additional overhead.

FS counters II
The experimental test-bed uses in-mem
maps
1. Precludes serious investigation of th
2. Remains for future work

Summary
The b-trees described here:
Are recoverableHave good concurrencyAre efficientHave good bounds on resource usaHave a good cloning strategy
Backup slides

Performance
In theory, top-down b-trees have a bottl
top
In practice, this does not happen becau
nodes are cached
In the experiments
1. Entries are 16bytes: key=8bytes, da
2. A 4KB node contains 70-235 entries

Test-bed
Single machine connected to a DS4500 
Fiber-Channel.
Machine: dual-CPU Xeon 2.4Ghz with 2Operating System Linux-2.6.9The b-tree on a virtual LUNThe LUN is a RAID1 in a 2+2 configuraStrip width is 64K, full stripe=512KBRead and write caching is turned off

Basic disk
performance
IO-size=4KBDisk-area=1GB
#threads op. time per op.(ms) op10 read N/A 12
write N/A 64R+W N/A 40
1 read 3.9 25
write 16.8 59R+W 16.9 59

Test methodolog
The ratio of cache-size to number of b-t
1. Is fixed at initialization time
2. This ratio is called the in-memory pe
Various trees were used, with the same 
experiments reported here are for tree

Tree T235
Maximal fanout: 235Legal #entries: 78 .. 235Contains 9.5 million keys and 65500 no
1. 65000 leaves
2. 500 index-nodes
Tree depth is: 4Average node capacity 150 keys

Test methodolog
Create a large tree using random operaFor each test
1. Clone the tree
2. Age the clone by doing 1000 random
insert-key/remove-key operations
3. Perform 104 – 108 measurements ag
with random keys
4. Delete the clone
Perform each measurement 5 times, anThe standard deviation was less than 1

measurements

lookup-key, insert-key, remove-key, app

extracted_fields.value: I am unable to extract the publication date of this document. While the provided text appears to be slides from a presentation about B-trees, shadowing, and cloning, there is no information about the date it was published.
